title: Self-XSS due to image URL can be eploited via XSSJacking techniques in review email

profile.name: Judge.me
profile.about: Judge.me powers the product reviews for e-commerce stores. Our apps help you collect and display reviews on Shopify, WooCommerce and BigCommerce.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
Good day team,

I found a self-xss due to the image url of recommendations in your reviewer profile that can be exploited via XSSJacking techniques. 

This one was honestly pretty tricky, since unlike the rest of the Judge.me App that whitelisted `*.myshopify.com` in the CSP this one has a set `X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN` meaning unlike the rest of my XSS reports I can use my Shopify store's frontent. Luckily though I managed to find a place that allows me to load iframes, namely the full email preview of review requests.

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Login to your 'reviewer' account in Judge.me

  1. Add a new recommendation for your public profile: `https://judge.me/[ID]?subtab=recommendations&tab=public_profile` -> Add recommendation

  1. Go back to the recommendation list, click the pencil icon in the image and insert this payload to trigger the Self-XSS: `https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/█████████.png?;'onload=alert(document.domain)>`

  1. Now to exploit this, login to your Shopify account and open the Judge.me app

  1. Click 'Request' -> 'Email Templates' and edit the existing email template

  1. In the 'text block', add a link and insert this payload as the display text and url (make sure to edit the ID to targeted reviewer's ID): `https://<iframe src="https://judge.me/[ID_OF_TARGET]?tab=public_profile">`
{F1510271}

  1. Click 'Save' two times. I'm honestly not sure why but it won't display properly unless you save it twice

  1. Now to send that template, create an order in your Shopify instance and make sure to fulfill that order: `yourshop.myshopify.com/admin/draft_orders/new` -> Mark as fulfilled. Make sure that the customer you use is the one from step 1 or the email of the reviewer account

  1.  Once that is done, go back to the Judge.me app and click 'Requests' -> 'Request Dashboard'

  1. Click 'Add manual request' -> 'Send Review Request for Old Orders'

  1. The reviewer account should receive an email notification regarding a review request, click 'Trouble viewing email' to access the full email preview

  1. In there you should see that the iframe for the reviewer account is visible, now all that is needed to be done is perform XSSJacking techniques to trigger the Self-XSS
{F1510279}

Note: Getting a valid review request that you can use for the preview is pretty confusing  since the 'send me an example' doesn't work for full email preview, it took me quite a while before I successfully managed to do it so if there's anything that I haven't explained properly please let me know or you can directly ask the Judge.me team for help :)

## Supporting Material/References:
{F1510278}

As usual, if there is anything that doesn't make any sense please let me know.

Cheers,
PenguinsHelp

## Impact

XSS via XSSJacking techniques

activities.message:
Hi @penguinshelp 

Thank you for your report. However, I'm having a bit of trouble understanding how the victim reaches the endpoint vulnerable to the HTML injection. Could you please provide the URL containing the `token` parameter? 

Thank you in advance for your help,
@croissants

Hi @croissants,

Thanks for the response. Once the victim receives the review request, simply go to the request email and click the 'Trouble viewing email?' 
{F1513931}

Here is my sample url:

https://judge.me/full_emails/review_request?token=be66ce5e-███████

Login to your Judge.me reviewer profile first and then visit that, you would then see your recommendations list displayed in the iframe
{F1513936}

(Note: as mentioned in the main report, using 'send me an example' to view the email wouldn't work that's why step 8 is important )

If you have any further questions please let me know :)

Have a nice day!

Cheers,
PenguinsHelp

Hi @penguinshelp,

According to your description, the behavior can be exploited to inject arbitrary HTML entities, although, the CSP limits the sphere of action from an attacker's perspective. From my knowledge, it's not possible to create fully customized pages under `*.myshopify.com`. Therefore, the injection, as is, won't pose any immediate security concerns.

Did you manage to exploit this further and mine a user's security? For instance, are you able to present the user with a custom-defined form and exfiltrate the credentials/data that a user is asked for?

Best,
@lugtag

Good day @lugtag,

>it's not possible to create fully customized pages under *.myshopify.com

I'm honesty not entirely sure as to what you mean by this since this is not performed in pages controlled by Shopify, please do correct me if I'm wrong.

The exploit I attempted to perform as POC don't require going through `*.myshopify.com`.  The vulnerable page is in the Judge.me full email preview sample link `https://judge.me/full_emails/review_request?token=be66ce5e-████████`. To edit that page, you would need to go through the Judge.Me Reviews app in shopify `Judge.Me app -> Requests -> Email templates -> Edit the template`. 

The attack scenario looks like this:

1. Reviewer/User creates an order on the shop
2. Shop sends a review request to the reviewer/user with the malicious template
3. Reviewer/User opens the email and then clicks 'Trouble viewing email' to open the full email preview page (under Judge.me)
4. That's where the exploit happens as shown in attachment F1510280:
{F1510280}

Hope this helps.

Have a nice day!

Cheers,
PenguinsHelp

Hi @penguinshelp 

Thanks a lot for the report! We are able to reproduce this. At first, we thought it was a self-XSS as it requires user to do many specific steps. However, like you say, this can enable clickjacking, turning self-XSS into reflect/stored XSS. 

We will work on a fix for this.
We have fixed the issue, can you please help retest this?

This one is a yes and no but I'll just put 'Yes' for the meantime since the exploit itself can't be reproduced anymore. 

First the self-xss in the reviewer's recommendation page due to image url is still there, I used the same payload in the first report and I can still reproduce it.
{F1531683}

Second the exploit itself can't be performed anymore (the XSSJacking) since there is a newly added frame-src CSP directive in the email preview page. This I can confirm is fixed preventing this way in being used to exploit the XSS via iframes.

I would still recommend the team fixing the self-xss though, since once I or any other user can find places that lacks this type of check the XSS can be used again.

Have a nice day!

Cheers,
PenguinsHelp
Thanks for the retest and for the suggestion! We will keep this in mind and will fix it at the earliest we can.
Requesting for disclosure on this one too :)
